metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (MUSOEXE-12)-Dataset of flux observation matrix（automatic meteorological station of No.2) (2012)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the automatic weather station (AWS) measurements from site No.2 in the flux observation matrix from 3 May to 21 September, 2012. The site (100.35406° E, 38.88695° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1559.09 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity (HMP45D; 5 m and 10 m, towards north), air pressure (AV-410BP; 2 m), rain gauge (52203; 10 m), wind speed (010C; 5 m and 10 m, towards north), wind direction (020C; 10 m, towards north), a four-component radiometer (CNR4; 4 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (IRTC3; 4 m,  vertically downward), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, and -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (ECh2o-5; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, and -1.0 m), and soil heat flux (HFT3; 3 duplicates with one below the vegetation and the other between plants, 0.06 m). 
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m, RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), air pressure (press, hpa), precipitation (rain, mm), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m, m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m, °), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation; W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IR_2, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2 and Gs_3, W/m^2), soil temperature profile (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, and Ts_100 cm, ℃), and soil moisture profile (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, and Ms_100 cm, %).
 The data processing and quality control steps were as follows. (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min; therefore, there were 144 records per day. The missing data were filled with -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) In this dataset, the time of 0:10 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:10; the data were stored in *.xlsx format. (5) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Additionally, 12 airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer were conducted.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Definition.Answer: The challenges in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces include the poor availability of data that can accurately represent the dynamic interactions across different spatial and temporal scales. This lack of data limits the ability to model and understand complex interactions within ecosystems, such as those found in oasis-desert regions, where diverse landscapes and climatic conditions coexist and interact.

Comparison.Question: How do the multiscale observational techniques used in the HiWATER experiment compare to the single-point flux measurement methods in terms of data collection for evapotranspiration studies?
Comparison.Answer: The multiscale observational techniques in the HiWATER experiment involve hierarchically nested scales capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, including a network of eddy covariance towers and remote sensing tools like LiDAR. In contrast, single-point flux measurement methods focus on localized data collection, such as using automatic meteorological stations or eddy covariance systems at specific points, which may not capture the spatial variability observed in heterogeneous landscapes.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in separating soil and vegetation component temperatures in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: In strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, challenges in separating soil and vegetation temperatures include image classification errors and uncertainties in atmospheric radiation and transmittance. Addressing these might involve using high-precision thermal cameras and techniques like the TSEB model to improve the accuracy of soil and canopy temperature calculations, thereby enhancing the estimation of evapotranspiration components.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be employed to ensure quality control of observational data in eco-hydrological research, and how do these methodologies contribute to the validity of research findings?
Interpretation.Answer: Quality control in eco-hydrological research can be ensured through sensor calibration, systematic data processing, and careful dataset generation, as demonstrated in the HiWATER project. These methodologies help maintain data integrity and validity, allowing for reliable research findings and supporting the exploration of eco-hydrological processes across diverse landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited availability of multiscale observations is a significant challenge in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. This is largely due to the complexity of instrumenting and capturing multiscale and multidisciplinary data across different landscapes, which requires a sophisticated setup of instruments at hierarchically nested scales, as was attempted in experiments like HiWATER.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes errors in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures are primarily due to image classification errors, which can vary with vegetation abundance. Misclassification can lead to incorrect temperature estimations, such as soil pixels being counted as vegetation pixels. Furthermore, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as uncertainties in the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy, can contribute to estimation errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the application of a two-source energy balance model influence the understanding of evapotranspiration processes in irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of a two-source energy balance model can enhance the understanding of evapotranspiration processes by providing separate estimates of soil and canopy fluxes, which is beneficial in accurately capturing the energy dynamics in irrigated agricultural areas characterized by strong advection.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating high-resolution thermal imaging data with traditional meteorological measurements on the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating high-resolution thermal imaging data with traditional meteorological measurements can lead to more accurate estimates of soil and canopy component temperatures, which is crucial for improving the separation of evaporation and transpiration components in evapotranspiration models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to implement a multiscale observation system for evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, which requires multiscale and multidisciplinary data. The HiWATER experiment is designed to obtain such data through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, facilitating a better understanding of these processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the use of soil and canopy component temperatures in estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to improve the accuracy of estimating these surface fluxes by using soil and canopy component temperatures, which offer better validation with observed ratios and measurements obtained through techniques like stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes and the eddy covariance system.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it crucial to utilize high-resolution thermal cameras for component temperature observations in the context of evapotranspiration estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras allows for the accurate separation of soil and canopy component temperatures, which is crucial for improving the performance of models like the TSEB in estimating latent fluxes and ratios of evaporation and transpiration, especially in strongly advective environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to ensure the quality control and preprocessing of eco-hydrological datasets collected from heterogeneous land surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control and preprocessing of eco-hydrological datasets involve ensuring a consistent data collection process, which includes steps like sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and the generation of datasets. This is crucial to maintain the integrity of the collected data and involves removing data with physical inconsistencies, handling missing data, and maintaining uniform date and time formats.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to collect and analyze multiscale and multidisciplinary data in eco-hydrological studies over heterogeneous surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection involves a hierarchical setup with various instruments like eddy covariance towers, meteorological stations, and remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers. This system captures the eco-hydrological processes across different scales, including oasis-desert interactions. Intensive observations are carried out at different scales, and the data are collected during specified intensive observation periods and through continuous monitoring.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate estimation of evapotranspiration using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras to measure soil and canopy component temperatures and the application of models like TSEB that only require a single measurement of land surface temperature enable the accurate estimation of evapotranspiration.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for implementing a multiscale observation system in an oasis-desert environment?
Enablement.Answer: Implementing a multiscale observation system in an oasis-desert environment requires a combination of flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, and synchronical ground measurements, with careful quality control in sensor calibration, data collection, and processing.

Expectation.Question: Why might multiscale observations be difficult to obtain in heterogeneous landscapes, and what strategies could improve data collection methods in these scenarios?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in eco-hydrological processes is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. To address this, HiWATER implemented intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations using a hierarchically nested scale approach. This included establishing a sparse network to capture oasis-desert interactions and employing a variety of instruments, such as EC towers and automatic meteorological stations, to collect comprehensive data across different landscapes.

Expectation.Question: What are some potential reasons for high uncertainty in estimating evapotranspiration in irrigated agricultural areas using remote sensing technologies?
Expectation.Answer: High uncertainty in estimating evapotranspiration can arise from errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from radiometric temperatures. Additionally, uncertainties are exacerbated by strong advective conditions in the region and errors caused by image classification, which can misclassify soil pixels as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimated canopy temperatures. Atmospheric factors, like ignoring upwelling radiation and transmittance, further contribute to the uncertainties.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in capturing the complexity of multiscale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, as seen in the HiWATER experiment, are designed to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data through a hierarchically nested instrumentation approach. However, challenges remain due to the limited availability of multiscale observations, indicating room for improvement in capturing the complexity of eco-hydrological processes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using thermal infrared cameras and ground-based measurements for estimating evapotranspiration (ET) in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Using thermal infrared cameras and ground-based measurements may face limitations due to errors in image classification, leading to inaccurate canopy and soil temperature estimations. Additionally, the strong advective environment can complicate the estimation of surface fluxes, impacting the reliability of ET calculations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection techniques in eco-hydrological studies can effectively capture multiscale observations across heterogeneous landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses this challenge by using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, such as a sparse network including a superstation, EC towers, and automatic meteorological stations placed in diverse landscapes to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. Additionally, airborne remote sensing missions involving LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and other tools were conducted to cover extensive areas, complementing ground-based measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the challenges faced in deriving accurate component temperatures for surface energy balance models and suggest possible improvements in data collection techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in deriving accurate component temperatures for surface energy balance models include image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, leading to misclassification of soil and vegetation pixels. This can result in overestimation of canopy temperature and subsequent errors in energy balance calculations. Additional uncertainties arise from ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as errors in estimating short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy. To improve data collection techniques, using high-resolution thermal cameras and implementing robust image classification algorithms may help in accurately separating soil and canopy temperatures, thereby enhancing the reliability of energy balance models.
